episode.title: Pharmaceutical Research & Manufacturers of America v. Walsh

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument next in Number 01-188, The Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America v. Kevin Concannon, et al.--
Mr. Phillips.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

Under 42 U.S.C. section 1396a, in subsection (a)(19), which is found on page 244 of the joint appendix, Congress made absolutely clear, as a singular precondition of all Medicaid plans, that they must assure that care and services will be provided in a manner consistent with simplicity of administration and the best interests of the recipients.
This statute does not allow Maine to use Medicaid recipients as pawns in its effort to reduce health care costs for those individuals who are not eligible for Medicaid.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Was this statute... was the statute discussed in the First Circuit opinion?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: The Medicaid statute?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The... the provision you just read.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Oh, absolutely, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Phillips, that... that provision is... is in the portion of the statute dealing with the approval of the State plan, a State plan has to have that consequence.
It has to serve the interest of the Medicaid recipients.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: That's true, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It doesn't say that each... each... each feature enacted by a State has to be judged individually under that standard.

It seems to me, why isn't it the case that if... if a State adopts some provision which does not comply with that provision, its plan is no longer a conforming plan, and the Secretary has explicit authority under the statute to... to repeal the Secretary's prior approval of the plan.
Why isn't that the way this thing should work?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, the way this operates is that this is not adopted as a part of the State's plan that's subjected to review by the Secretary of HHS.

What this is, is a completely separate program that's been adopted independently, and all it does is reach out and hold the recipients of Medicaid as hostages in order to extract money from out-of-state manufacturers--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Yes, but do you--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --but it's not a part of the plan.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --but is it... is it the case, if we were to, let's suppose, affirm here, that the Health & Human Services head could nonetheless call a halt to it and say, you no longer conform with our understanding of what's required, you're holding hostage our Medicaid recipients and it's having a negative effect on them because of the prior approval requirements of drugs that otherwise wouldn't be required?
Is... would... would the Secretary have that power?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I believe the Secretary might have that power, although I would ask you to ask Mr. Kneedler when... when he's arguing.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, I probably will.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: But over and above that, that doesn't... but that's not an exclusive remedy, that's all.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But how can the authorization provision and the requirements attached to the authorization provision, how can that conceivably not be part of the State plan, as you say?
I mean, it seems to me it's central to the--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, I mean--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --there's an authorization--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --there's a... there's a formalistic way of looking at it, which is that they have a State plan, and this is not incorporated as part of the State plan.
What this has been... what has been done here is to adopt a completely separate program which simply reaches out, as I said before, and seeks to hold hostage certain elements of it.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --But if you take that position, the State plan could be rendered meaningless.
I mean, the State plan simply becomes a kind of formal Open Sesame.
The... there's got to be power to look, as Justice Scalia suggests, or the State plan means nothing.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, no, there has to be a State plan.
The question is whether or not (a)(19) reflects congressional intent that the State has to act in a particular way.
If it acts contrary to that way, the only question then is, are there multiple remedies available to respond to it?
I think, Justice O'Connor, the answer to your question is yes.
I think the Secretary does have that authority to go forward, although I would ask Mr. Kneedler--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Can I ask this question: Could the State, if it just... without adopting a Maine Rx program, just decide, we want to take a good, hard look at every sale of drugs that comes into our State, so we're going to subject every drug manufacturer to prior approval pursuant to 1396r-8(d), could they do that?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --I... there's an open question as to whether they could do that.
Certainly, if you take the most expansive reading of 1396r-8(d) you could make that argument.
The alternative argument would be to what extent that violates or interferes with the formulary formulations that are embedded in the statute.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But if they do have that authority, and you say that's an open question, doesn't it follow, a fortiori, that they can do what they're doing here?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No, it doesn't follow a fortiori, because what they're doing here is imposing the prior authorization with respect to, you know, to serve purposes that are completely unrelated to the Medicaid program.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, maybe my hypothetical was completely unrelated.

They just want to be sure you can open the caps on the drug containers, or whatever it might be, some idiocentric... I don't think that the... as I read it, I don't see anything in that provision that says it must serve a Medicaid purpose.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, I think you'd have to read that provision in the context of the entirety of that provision providing for coverage of drugs, and I think you have to do it in that context, and I think there are broader issues there, but the singular problem here, obviously, is that if you interpret the statute as broadly as the State of Maine does to say that we can impose prior authorization requirements, then what they can say is, we want to extract money from manufacturers solely for the purpose of building schools or roads or anything else that we want to, and there's no restriction on that, and it seems to me that if what you're saying is you want to have prior authorization as a mechanism to deal within Medicaid, to provide generally for a balance of interest between Medicaid recipients, that's one thing.

But what... what... what Maine is doing is using Medicaid recipients to further completely unrelated purposes of the State, then it seems to me what you've done is essentially ask the Federal Government to subsidize a program that... that's not an appropriate one to subsidize.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay, what about the halfway measure, and the halfway measure has been described by the Government as... as some instances of prior approval that, that it would authorize that go beyond what the... the... the... the very strict enforcement of Medicaid in a limited sense would require.
Do you think what the Government has... excuse me.
Do you think what the Government has suggested is also beyond the authorization of the statute?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I think it is.

I think the better way to read the statute is to recognize that this is designed to benefit Medicaid recipients, and the problem is, once you get past programs that are designed to benefit recipients themselves, it's very difficult to see where you draw the line after that in terms of where it goes.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, is it correct that the Secretary has approved a few plans in other States that do go beyond, technically, the direct Medicaid recipients, for instance, the people who are very close to the line and might well become eligible soon?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Justice O'Connor, that is correct.
They have approved those programs.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Those programs are in litigation as we stand here--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Uh-huh.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --as I stand here today, and--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Is that possible... I mean, as I'm seeing this at the moment, if the State uses the authorization program for any purpose at all, we know that some... that some Medicaid recipients will be hurt.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: If a Medicaid recipient walks into a drugstore and asks for drug X, that recipient can get it more easily if it's not on this prior approval list than if it is, and that being so, it must be impermissible under Federal law, unless the object of the program achieves a Medicaid-related purpose, so the question in front of us is, does it?
Now, what's bothering me about that is that the Secretary thinks some programs like Maine's are okay, and others maybe not.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So in my mind the words, primary jurisdiction, suddenly flash red.

How can I decide this case without knowing what the Secretary thinks, and how can... I mean, after all, if the Secretary says this one is okay, that would have a big leg up under Chevron, and if the Secretary says no, it wouldn't, so why isn't the correct principle primary jurisdiction, which we can apply whether the parties like it or not, and why isn't the correct result here to send it back to the district court and say, district court, Maine cannot put this into effect until they ask the Secretary about it?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well, I don't have any particular problem with sending it back to the district court enjoined subject to approval by the Secretary of HHS, I mean, if that's the way the Court wanted to resolve this case.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, I'm really... that's not what I want.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I want to have--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Is that the way primary jurisdiction works?

I thought there has to be in place some mechanism for getting the agency to pass upon the question, a mechanism that the person who is dismissed from Federal court is entitled to use, and I'm not sure that exists here.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I don't know, Justice Scalia, that you need to be dismissing it from Federal court.
I think it's quite possible for the--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, even if you sit on it until it's done--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Right, stay your hand pending--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --you still have to assure that there's some... some mechanism.
I mean, all the primary jurisdiction cases I know of, there... there was a means to file a case before the agency.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well, I don't disagree with that, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, I disagree with it, so we'll have to work it out.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You can't just send them off and say, you know, ask the Secretary, by the way, and have the Secretary write us a letter.
I don't know that we've ever done that.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, I'm not sure that there isn't a mechanism for asking the... to petition the Secretary for review.
I think if Maine wanted to get approval of this particular program, it certainly had it available to do that.
It didn't seek that particular course.
And Justice Breyer, I think it's important, in the context of trying to figure out primary jurisdiction, we know the views of the United States with respect to this particular program.
There may be other programs, as Justice O'Connor identified, that come close to the line where the Secretary would have a different view, and I think it's appropriate in--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Is their views the Secretary's view?

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: That's what I--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --I'll... fine, I'll ask them.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --I believe it is the Secretary's view, but--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Phillips, as I understand your position, so long as it benefits Medicaid recipients, any... any authorization scheme is okay?
I mean, a State can say, we'll authorize your drug if you pay $5 to each Medicaid recipient?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --That is not my position.

My basic position is that the Court doesn't need to figure out precisely what prior authorizations are permissible in order to decide this case, because the one thing that should be absolutely clear is, you cannot use this mechanism in a Federal program in order to disadvantage the primary recipients of that program without serving any Medicaid, sort of, related purpose.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You... you... you may be up in a... in a later case arguing that the... that the reasonable reading of the authorization requirement is... is to assure the safety of the drug, or the necessity of the drug for the particular illness?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: That... that's absolutely correct, Justice Scalia.

We'd... we... I mean, I think we would take that position, and that we... that you cannot read (d)(1) completely in isolation, and... and to the fullest extent of the language of that, without regard to the rest of the provisions of (d)(1) through (d)(6), and you... and for sure, you cannot read them without regard to the more fundamental requirement in subsection (a) and (a)(19), that the primary consideration must be the beneficiaries of this program.

They are the most needy people in our country, and the notion that you use them as a mechanism for trying to simply lower health care costs for the Steven Kings of the world strikes me as... as an outrageous position for the State of Maine to take.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No, but they may not be doing that.
They may think that the object of this is to lower the health care costs for the moderately poor not yet on Medicaid, and thereby prevent people from falling into the Medicaid category.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Justice Breyer, that would be a persuasive argument if this statute had any kind of a tailoring mechanism to it whatsoever.
It is open to all residents who are otherwise not covered by--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Maine says those are never caught--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Administrative regulations, one of the things that Maine said was, you've stopped us at the threshold.

We could have regulations that say, for example, people who are covered by insurance will not have access to this benefit, but on the question... you said would... you would be content if the Court said, the Secretary has to look at it, until then it's no good.
Would you have... this is the... your lawsuit.
Could you have gone to the Secretary and say, said, Secretary, we want you to look at this, the Secretary says, I'm busy with a dozen other things and I don't want to look at it?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --I don't know of any statutory mechanism for a third party to come in and ask the Secretary to review a State plan.
I don't know that... I don't know that there's anything that prevents anyone from sending a letter to the Secretary to ask him to take, to undertake that.
That said, the Secretary obviously knows about this particular scheme.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Yes, and the Secretary, you said that the... at least the SG supports your view that this... that this program of Maine's is impermissible, but the SG also told us, essentially, that this case wasn't ripe, so we shouldn't have granted cert. I mean, that was the SG's first position, that this is a... we don't know what, in fact, the Maine scheme is, because it was never... it never went into effect, because you got an injunction.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: But the one thing that we absolutely know about the Maine scheme, and it... Justice Breyer described it, is that every Medicaid recipient is placed at risk by the prior authorization scheme.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes, but Mr. Phillips, are there any findings that any Medicaid recipient has actually been harmed by this program?
I... this is a--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, because there was a joinder--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --one of the things that bothers me, I don't know that we have any findings by the district court as to what the real impact will be.
I know your... your... the Government says this is going to happen--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well, if--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --but if everybody agreed, for example, to join the Maine program, maybe it may work out fine.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --The... I don't have to go to the United States.
The State of Maine concedes in its brief at page 25, Maine Rx can be expected to trigger prior authorization more often than previously.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes, but it may well be that prior authorization would, in turn, lead to some solution between the drug companies and the State as to how this will all be handled.
I don't think the fact they agreed that it would trigger prior authorization necessarily proves the conclusion that the Medicaid recipients will be harmed.
It may well be true, but I'm just not sure--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, but--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --the record supports that--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --as of this stage of the case.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well, but there'd be no way to enjoin the program before going into effect, which means that you essentially have to wait until actual Medicaid recipients are deprived of drugs in order to be able to implement... to stop a program that on its face does nothing to benefit Medicaid beneficiaries, and clearly poses a serious threat to them.
I... if we go back to the Hines v. Davidowitz language, it talks about the full achievement of Congress' objectives.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But it only opposes the very threat that the statute by its own terms authorizes.
That's the threat.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, but it only authorizes--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The threat of prior approval which the statute authorizes.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Sure.
It... to serve Medicaid-related purposes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But the statute doesn't say that.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I... I understand that, Justice Stevens, but the point is that if you read the statute, and it's essentially six, those six words, to say that the State has unlimited authority to do that, it strikes me as inconceivable that Congress would have allowed this entire mechanism to be available for the State to come in and simply to raise revenue from out-of-State manufacturers.
There is no rational basis for that kind of a conclusion.
The much more sensible way to narrow the statute is to say, if it serves other Medicaid purposes, then that's an appropriate way to proceed.
If it doesn't, then it seems to me the... the Court has to conclude that the best interests of the beneficiaries ultimately has to trump here under these circumstances.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Phillips, do you also rely on the Commerce Clause as somehow prohibiting what Maine has done--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --and if so, how do you make that argument?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well, Justice O'Connor, we have sort of three components to that argument.
The thing that is... I concede at the outset that there is no case of this Court that directly controls in either direction.
This is a unique scheme that's been adopted here, and... and--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Is there anything in the Commerce Clause that prevents a State from addressing within its State boundaries requirements for dispensing prescription drugs?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well, when the entire burden of the program falls out of State, it seems to us that this creates at least a serious question about what's going on here.
The--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, any State regulation, a State wants to have a special rule for a bicycle, you could say, well, that increases the cost to the manufacturer and the other States have to pay for it, so I'm... I'm not sure that that reasoning, which was in your brief, carries the day.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well, I--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Like a special fuel requirement for automobiles?
Do you think California can set certain standards, that of course it affects the auto manufacturers?
They don't make them in California.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Yes.

There's no question that States are free to create certain types of regulations that are different from other States, and that's... and that's not the full sweep of the argument that we're making here.
What... what--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: That's not what happened here.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --No, that's--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: I don't understand the Commerce Clause argument.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --I wouldn't presume to try to teach you about the Commerce Clause, Justice O'Connor, but the reality of what's happening here is much more like the West Lynn Creamery case, where what you're talking about is the payment of a subsidy, all by out-of-state entities, in order to benefit... in that case it was to benefit in-state competitors.
There are no in-state competitors in this case.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Oh, I've got quite--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --Isn't that a--
--a problem with the argument.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That was the problem.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I didn't hear--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well... no, let me yield to Justice Kennedy.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I had thought you might make the argument... I didn't see it in your brief, maybe I missed it... that this is just so burdensome on manufacturers to go from State to State to State that it's just an... it's an undue burden on an interstate transaction, period.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Under Pike v. Bruce Church.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And... and Southern Pacific v. Arizona.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yeah.
The reason we didn't raise that argument is that we thought that we would require... in order to make that argument we would require more factual findings by the district court--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --in order to get into it, because there's a balancing component to that--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: The other thing I wondered about is, if you've come over Vermont or New York you can't have the advantage of this.
I suppose it's not necessarily in your interest to argue that it has to be expanded to other States, but I... it seems to me that also was a questionable part of the program.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well, I do think one of the real problems with this program is that some States will adopt this kind of a scheme and other States won't adopt this kind of a scheme, which means that you're going to have inherent discrimination with respect to consumers.

Some consumers will benefit to the detriment of other consumers, and it does seem to me that... that the theory of West Lynn Creamery was designed to say that you don't just look at the competitors and the relationships between them, you have to look more broadly at the manufacturers, the wholesalers, all the retailers, and all the way down to the consumers, and if you have the kind of discriminatory effects here where Maine seizes for itself all the economic benefits and imposes on... on everyone else the economic burdens, that in that circumstance this runs afoul of the core--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The... wasn't this--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --command of the Commerce Clause.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --one of the reasons the First Circuit vacated the injunction, the fact that there just hadn't been any factual development here as to what was happening?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, that was part... yes, to be sure, Mr. Chief Justice, that's part of what they said.
On the other hand, if you accept our basic theory about the clear discriminatory implication of the way the scheme operates, that kind of an operation is per se invalid.
That's what the Court held in... in West Lynn Creamery.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But isn't the West Lynn Creamery difficulty in your argument that here, unlike West Lynn, there are no entities within the same category, manufacturers, e.g., producers, for example, some of whom are being discriminated in favor of others?
What's going on here is not discrimination by the State within a given class to benefit the members of the class within the State.

What is going on here is a scheme which happens to fall on certain individuals in a manufacturing class who, incidentally, are out of State, for the benefit of people in a different class, that is, the consumers, who are in-State, and West Lynn doesn't govern that.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No, it doesn't directly cover that, and I conceded that at the outset.
On the other hand, the point here is that there are entities out there in the stream that are within Maine, and on whom this burden is not imposed.

It was chosen to impose the burden strictly on the manufacturers, and it is done in a way that will create disparate impacts with respect to consumers in Maine versus consumers in other... in other States--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But that is... I mean, that's a... that's a necessary consequence of the prior approval scheme.
That... you're going to have that argument no... no matter how... no matter how prior approval--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well, and... and if it operates within Medicaid, it seems to me that there's no... there's no significant argument to be made there, because Congress has basically taken it over.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --Simply because you've got to have it.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: But otherwise... and one last point I'd like to make, which is simply that the Commerce Clause issue does not need to be addressed in the event the Court holds that the, that the Maine statute is preempted.
If... I'd like to reserve the balance of my time.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Phillips.
Mr. Kneedler.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

The Department of Health & Human Services has articulated a position on two issues that are directly relevant to this case, and those positions are set forth in the letter to the State Medicaid directors that is set forth in an appendix to our brief at page, I believe it's page 45a it begins.
The first of those--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, does that lead to a conclusion as to its view as to this program that we're considering?
Is it valid, or isn't it?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --If I could... there are two problems--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: As far as the Secretary is concerned.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --There are two problems with the... with the State program under this Medicaid director's letter that the Secretary sent out.

The first is that it's the position of the department that a plan such as this, which imposes a prior approval requirement for Medicaid patients, if the drug manufacturer does not pay rebates with respect to sales to nonMedicaid patients, that sort of change is a material change in the State's plan which requires the approval of a plan amendment.

There is a regulation that we cite in our brief at page 28, and quote, that requires that, and that, by the way, I think could be the... the mechanism effectively for a prior jurisdiction sort of approach.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I see that, but I... I mean, I'm a little bit at sea.
I absolutely wouldn't call it primary jurisdiction.

The label doesn't matter, but the... the... but... now, where I'm... where I'm... where I'm at sea is at figuring out whether it's possible to say, and you don't say this in your brief, that... that a program like Maine's, which is arguably, arguably wrong, or arguably right, that it can't go into effect without the prior approval of HHS.
Now, that's going to require me to look up the approval statutes, a whole lot of things that weren't briefed.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: Well, it's... the... the... we have cited this regulation in our brief, and the... and under Allens v. Robbins the Secretary's, or the... the Secretary's interpretation's set forth in the brief.
It's also set forth in the Medicaid director's letter.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why hasn't the Secretary acted under it, then?
What are you bothering us for?

If the Secretary has power under this... under this regulation to stop this plan from going forward because it amounts to an amendment of the... of the plan, and an amendment that hasn't been approved, the... the Secretary has the power to stop it.
Why... you know, why--

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --do we have to get involved?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --Well, if I could just answer that and then move to the second question, because I think it's related, the regulation identifies what... that material changes in the plan have to be submitted for an amendment.

The Secretary's enforcement authority comes from a different source, which is in 42 U.S.C. 1396c, which allows the Secretary to cut off funds in whole or in part if a State is operating under a plan that requires an amendment because of those changes, so... but I--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well then, why doesn't the Secretary do it?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --I think it was... it's entirely reasonable... first of all, that's a matter of enforcement discretion under Heckler v. Cheney, and at least for the time being, why this... while this case is under... is under submission, the Secretary has not... has not proceeded.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, but I think the Secretary is ignoring one serious problem, and I suspect it's behind Justice Scalia's question.
It's certainly in my mind.
It's one thing for the Secretary to act within enforcement power.

It's one thing for the Secretary to interpret the regs by, the statute by regulations that are subject to Chevron deference, but if the Secretary does neither one of those things, and from one side of the Secretary's mouth we hear, well, yes, some prior approval beyond what is strictly necessary for the direct benefit of Medicaid recipients is okay, but this goes a little bit goes too far, courts are then placed in the position of saying, well, can we read the statute so precisely as to say that the Secretary's position of what is okay is okay and, by going this step further, there's a violation of the statute?

We are placed in a very difficult position, in effect by the Secretary, by you, in being asked to draw a line with a very fine pencil, whereas if the Secretary wants to act under administrative authority, presumably that's the end of it.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: Well, in going forward, I mean, the Secretary issued this Medicaid director's letter in September, after the Court had granted review--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Ah.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --because this was an area that required attention.
Going forward, we... we expect that... that States will submit their proposals to the Secretary as plan amendments--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, is there some--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --And if--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --Is there some mechanism by... or authority by which we could somehow refer this back to the district court to seek some kind of information from the Secretary?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --Well, here's the way I think that it could proceed.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: How... how could we do it?
I don't know of a doctrine but--

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: I... I think the procedural posture of this case would allow that, and let me explain why.

The Secretary's second position in this case, which I wanted to also make sure I articulated, which was that a... that a proposed, or a plan such as this, which provides for rebates for nonMedicaid patients, still must serve some Medicaid purpose.

In the district court, when the district court entered what is only a preliminary injunction at this stage, at page 71 of the petition appendix, the district court pointed out that the State had not argued that its proposal served any Medicaid purpose.
As the preliminary injunction was entered, it was entered on that premise.

The court of appeals then speculated that perhaps it does serve a Medicaid purpose, but looking back at when the preliminary injunction was entered, it was entered on the premise that it served none, and we think, and the Secretary believes that a plan must at least serve some Medicaid purpose.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --But as I understand it, Mr. Kneedler, it is... it is at least theoretically possible that the Secretary could approve this very plan.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: If... on the proper showing.
The rationale--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Right, of course.
It needs more facts.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --Yes.
The rationale adopted by the district court was the rationale that some--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes.
It may have now advanced a Medicaid-related purpose that may or may not be sufficient.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --That's... but we believe that the purpose that has been advanced does not save this statute.

The purpose that has been advanced and was identified by the court of appeals was a purpose that some people who were close to being Medicaid-eligible will be forced to spend more on drugs, may become Medicaid-eligible, and therefore cost the Medicaid program more money.
That's a Medicaid-related purpose.
The problem is, the State statute is not tailored to people who are close to the poverty line.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So is the procedure--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --Would you... would you finish your response to me--

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: Yes.
What--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --to tell me--

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --what it is that you think we could do?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: If the Court reversed the court of appeals decision, in effect affirmed the district court's injunction, which was entered on the basis that the plan serves no Medicaid-related purpose, the State program would be enjoined.

At that point the State of Maine could submit the program to the Secretary of Health & Human Services along with any justifications for the plan, such as those... there are two additional ones that have been raised in its brief in this Court for the first time, and we think that's how it should play out.
This is a... right now, the case presents a very narrow issue on a preliminary injunction.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Why couldn't that procedure be followed by affirming, and saying there should be a hearing in the district court on these very issues that you're raising, and both sides would present the facts?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: We don't think it would be a hearing in the district court.

We believe it should be submitted to the Secretary, because a plan amendment is required, but we do believe that... that the petitioner has made a sufficient showing based on the, on what the district court said, that this plan, that Maine had offered no justification, no Medicaid justification for the plan.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Do you read the statutory authorization for prior approval to mean prior approval only if there's a Medicaid-related benefit?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: We... we do.
The legislative history of the prior approval position--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You rely entirely on legislative history for that?

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --No, and also there are two other provisions of the act which we think are relevant, on the one hand, a19, which talks about the best interests of the patients, but on the other hand, a(30)... this is 1396a(30)(A), which says that a State plan must provide for methods of payment that advance efficiency and economy in the Medicaid program.

We think both of those speak to interests within the Medicaid program and require in the prior approval process, as well as in the administration of the plan generally, weighing the interests of the Medicaid beneficiaries against the broader institutional interests of the Medicaid program.

If there was no Medicaid-related purpose requirement at all, then a State could impose a prior approval requirement if the drug company contributes money to the art museum or to the State highway program.
We think that under this Court's decision in Dublino, the State must be pursuing a purpose in common with the Federal Government, a Medicaid-related purpose.
What... what the scope--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Kneedler, it... it was the Government's first position that this Court ought to let the case ripen, and now you... you are necessarily taking a position in this lawsuit because we granted cert, but the Government made a pretty good argument essentially that this case wasn't ripe.

turn.speaker: edwin_s_kneedler
turn.label: Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
turn.text: --Well, ripe for this Court's review, but we now... we now believe that, given that the director's letter that was sent out in September, that there is a basis, there's an articulation of the Secretary's position both on plan amendments and the requirement of a Medicaid-related purpose that... that this Court could properly dispose of this case in the narrow... in the narrow way I suggested which, of course, would also obviate any requirement to consider the Commerce Clause question.
Things have evolved in the Secretary's evaluation of this and, as Justice O'Connor, I think pointed out, the Secretary has since approved a Michigan plan amendment under this same general approach.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Kneedler.
Mr. Hagler, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court:
People without insurance are charged more for prescription drugs than any other purchaser in the market, often much more.
Patients who are forced to pay cash at the pharmacy are those least able to absorb these high prices.

To ameliorate this hardship, the Maine legislature will embrace a market-based approach used by other large third party purchasers to leverage its purchasing power under... as a third party purchaser in Medicaid to obtain price relief for the uninsured in Maine.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And you think that's one of the valid uses of the authorization provision?
You think that's why it was included in the statute, so that a State could... could shake down drug companies to lower prices to other people?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: I concede that... that Congress never thought that Maine might use prior authorization in the way that Maine Rx anticipates it.
However, what Congress said--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You can use it for anything at all?
Could... could you use it to... to say, we... you know, you... you have to pay each member of the Maine legislature $100 a year?
Could... could you put that in there?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --As you get further and further for the purposes of... of providing health care, you approach uses a... of prior authorization that might offend Congress and this Court, but preemption is a question for Congress.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, did Maine offer in the district court, in the hearings on whether a preliminary injunction should issue, a justification for how the Maine Rx program benefits Medicaid patients?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: We did not so argue in the district court.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: When you say... who does it apply to?
That is, the statute says it applies to qualified residents.
They define that as people with a Maine Rx enrollment card, and now I don't know who those people are.
Is it virtually everybody in the State?
Is it a small subclass, those who don't have insurance?
Who is it?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: Well, it's... it's those without insurance.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So that's a fairly small group.
What percentage of that... it's 15 percent of the people of Maine?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: If... we anticipate 22 percent.
The AARP has a different--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Okay, so 15, 22 percent.
Now, if that being so, it sounds to me like it could be like the one that was approved, or maybe it's not like the one that was approved.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --And you don't know--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: It sounds like a case, to me, that has to go to the Secretary, whose job it is to approve it, rather than having us fly blind.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --Well, here's the difference between what the Secretary approved and what the Maine... and... and what he's proposing with respect to Maine Rx and the plan amendments.
What the Secretary approved was a program that's a demonstration project, a waiver program, allowing more people into Medicaid notwithstanding the fact that they're ineligible.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: That has been approved for Maine?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: Approved and struck down by the D.C. Circuit on Christmas Eve.
The Secretary and the Solicitor General, the Secretary and the Solicitor General identified the fact that that program helped people up to 300 percent of poverty.
Without the Healthy Maine program, the demonstration project, Maine Rx is now the only program that helps those people.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: That isn't an answer to my question.
The answer to my... my question was, it sounds to me like a program that the Secretary might approve or might not approve, and so why should we fly blind?
Why isn't it the case that you can't put this program into effect, given Federal law, without the approval of the Secretary?
Now, when she approves it or disapproves it, they can argue about whether that was legal.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: Well, the Secretary is suggesting that the State of Maine seek a plan amendment, but by definition, a plan amendment allows... a plan amendment is something that, if we sought a plan amendment to run Maine Rx it would necessarily be allowed by the Medicaid statute.
42... the Medicaid statute, 1396 subsection--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I'm not following you.
Is your argument that--

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --We don't--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --even if the Secretary disapproved this, were it a plan, we still could do it?
If that's your argument, I'll answer that question.
That's a legal question.
I think it's an easy one to answer.
In my mind, the answer's no.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --Well, if the Secretary were to--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Now, you can explain why it shouldn't be no, but I want to know if that's what I'm supposed to decide.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --It's not what you're supposed to decide.
The Secretary has not acted, other than speaking to this Court through the brief of the Solicitor General.
The Medicaid statute provides a mechanism for the Secretary to tell the State when it is running its Medicaid program in a fashion which violates the provisions of the Medicaid statute.
That is--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but is this actually a... the... the State... the State of Maine running its Medicaid program, it... it's a freestanding statute, isn't it?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --It's an entirely different... correct, it's an entirely different statute.
We don't believe we need a plan amendment to seek approval to run the Maine Rx program.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: That's fine.
So then you want me to decide the question of whether it would be possible to have this statute even if the Secretary, were it an amendment to the Medicaid plan, would say no, okay?
I say that's a legal question we can decide.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: But you should not decide that now.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Is that what you think we should decide now?
Are you following what I'm saying or not?
Am I not--

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: Not precisely.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --I can decide the question if the Sec... you're saying... suppose the Secretary's approval makes no difference.
Let us assume the Secretary would disapprove it.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: There would... a legal question, can you have this statute anyway?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Okay.
That's what you think we should decide?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: I believe that's what I--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right.
If that's what you think we should decide, fine, then why isn't the answer to that question clearly no?

You would have a Federal statute, it uses the Federal program, the Secretary thinks it's contrary to the Federal program, the Secretary's views are within her authority, let's say, under the... under the Federal program, and so a State cannot put something into effect--

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --that is so clearly contrary to the Medicaid program using the Medicaid device.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --The question that this... the first question that this Court certified was, as described in the Secretary's brief, is whether the Federal Medicaid statute allows the use of that authority under the statute to compel... the prior authorization authority--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And I assume it--

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --And he says yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --And it would be a waste of time and money for us to send it back to the Secretary, at least if we are convinced on the basis of the briefs submitted here, that even if the Secretary did approve it, that approval would be invalid.
I mean, you would concede that--

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: If the--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --that whatever primary jurisdiction is involved here--

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --If the--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --it certainly makes no sense to send it back to the Secretary if, when the Secretary approves it, there is then a lawsuit and we say, oh, by the way, he couldn't approve this.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: This goes too far.
We might as well decide that now, no?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: You can decide the preemption question now, and I think that the Court should, and the preemption question is whether Congress intended to prohibit what Maine has here done.

When Congress legislates against the backdrop of the preemption doctrine and it give... gave to the State the discretion to subject to prior authorization any covered outpatient drug, it qualified that discretion hardly at all.
The only qualifications are the two provisions, the procedural safeguards that require that if prior authorization is sought--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Doesn't the Secretary have some discretion in this area as to whether to say it's good or bad, the... the Maine plan, or are you saying it's simply not his business?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --It's Congress' business--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, right.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --to set the line--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But did Congress in what it enacted leave any room for the Secretary to have some discretion here?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --What Congress enacted was the opportunity for the Secretary to tell the State that when it's begun a program or is operating its Medicaid program out of compliance with the Medicaid statute, that it believes that that's the case, and the provision provides for a fair hearing for the State, we get together with the Secretary, we try to work it out.
If we can't, and if the Secretary... if Maine persists in wanting to run the program, and the Secretary disapproves the program, then his remedy is to withhold money from the State and--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But if... if it's a freestanding pro... if it's a freestanding statute, not part of Maine's Medicaid, how can the Secretary disapprove a freestanding statute?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --What he can do is look to the effect of what happens once Maine Rx is implemented, and look to the effect on the Medicaid beneficiaries as to whether or not they'll be harmed.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, the Secretary theoretically could conclude already that to require prior approval for every prescription drug will have negative effects on Medicaid recipients who otherwise would not have to seek prior approval, because there's quite a bit in the record about the difficulty when prior approval must be obtained.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: Oh, I submit there... that there's... I disagree with respect to the record.

I believe that there's very little in the record which demonstrates that there will be any harm to Maine Rx beneficiaries, harm to their health, once Maine Rx is imposed, and should the State ultimately impose prior authorizations under the Maine Rx statute.
You have lodging materials which are untested.

The fact of the matter is, if we were to return to the district court we could demonstrate, based on a vigorous use of prior authorization in the 2 years that have intervened the granting of the injunction and today, that we are imposing prior authorization and we are answering the phone in less than 2 hours, and that Medicaid patients are, in fact, not being harmed.
We... our position is that to survive a facial challenge the petitioner must demonstrate that any use of prior authorization, as contemplated by the Maine Rx--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, I question whether this is correctly described as a facial challenge.
You think of a facial challenge more in terms of somebody who has a... First Amendment implications, or at least criminal law applications.

This... as I read the First Circuit's opinion, although they talked about a facial challenge, I thought what they were saying was, we just don't know enough, since the thing had never gone into effect to uphold the injunction.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --No, and... and what the First Circuit didn't know was how the program would actually be implemented, and there are many ways of implementing the program that not only will not cause harm to Medicaid beneficiaries, but which will affirmatively advance the purposes of Medicaid.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Is the program now in a... being operated?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: It is not, and the reason that it's not is because the--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: The way you spoke, I thought you had some current experience.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --We do have current experience with the use of prior authorization to save Medicaid money.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: For Medicaid, for Medicaid patients.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: For Medicaid, correct, and as a result of that experience we know much more about our abilities and would be able to describe to the district court much more about our abilities should the First Circuit--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Why wasn't the plan put into effect if the injunction was lifted?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --The mandate was stayed pending--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Oh, I see.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --for a writ of certiorari, so we've... we've not had an opportunity to implement the program.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But the Federal Government, with reference to Medicaid, certainly thinks prior authorization is an important enforcement mechanism and now you're saying oh, don't worry about it, it doesn't make much difference.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: That's hard for me to accept.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --Well, the Federal Government agrees that prior authorization... prior authorization is undeniably a cost-saving measure.
That's the primary purpose why Congress permitted the States broad discretion to impose prior authorization.

Under the Maine Rx program, what the State is saying to manufacturers is, please negotiate with us, and if you don't negotiate with us, we will review the drugs that you manufacture to see and determine, on a drug-by-drug basis, whether it would be appropriate to subject those drugs to prior authorization.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But the very reason you put that on the bargaining table is because you know it's going to... it's going to slow down the sales of some of these drugs.
Incidentally, I... and you can answer that.
I take it that if Company X has 10 different drugs, and it can't agree with you on the rebate price for just one, that all of those drugs must have prior authorization, or am I wrong about that?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: I believe that you're wrong.
I believe that... that the Secretary has the discretion--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I read the Government's brief to the contrary, but I'll take a look at it.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --Yeah, I believe--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: You're representing that it's drug-by-drug, so a company can agree with you as to nine of the drugs, and those will not be subject to prior authorization, but only the tenth drug, as to which you can't agree, will be subject to prior authorization?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --I believe--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: That's your representation?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --As to the... I believe that our administrative rules demonstrate, proposed administrative rules that the Department hasn't enacted because the injunction has been imposed allow the Department of Human Services of the State of Maine to look on a drug-by-drug basis as to whether any particular drug ought to be subjected to prior--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Does it allow it, if it uses, to look on a company-by-company basis, as I'd first described?
In other words, does it subject--

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --What will happen is, if--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --to discretion of the State.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --In other words, if Pfizer were to agree to provide a rebate for some of its drugs but not all of its drugs, must we look to the other drugs--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --and determine prior authorization?
The statute contemplates a negotiation.
The Commissioner is to use his best efforts to negotiate with manufacturers in order to--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I take that to be a yes?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --The answer is yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You can keep all of their drugs off unless they give you what you want for some of them?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: We could, but the statute also allows us not to.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Yeah.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: The purpose of that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You could, that's... and... and you say it... that the statute envisions using this authorization as a cost-saving measure.
Does this save any costs... does this statute save any cost to the Medicare recipients?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --To the Medicare?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: To... to the Medicaid--

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: Oh, the Medicaid recipients, the Medicaid recipients themselves pay nothing, but it can save money in, and it's probable that it will save money in the Medicaid program, and the reason for that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --I understand, because some people won't come into the program who otherwise would come in.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --Well, that's what the First Circuit picked up on, but the other reason and the other method in which it would save Medicaid money is, it would result in shifting prescribing behavior from more expensive drugs to less expensive drugs.
The Commissioner, under subsection--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But doesn't that depend on who you make the deals with?
Maybe the more expensive drug... drugs we're willing to make this deal with you, and the less expensive not willing.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --Subsection 13 of the Maine Rx statute gives to the Commissioner the discretion to run the Medicaid program and the maine Rx program in a coordinated manner so as to enhance efficiencies in both, and so I believe that the Commissioner would never impose prior authorization on the cheapest drug in a therapeutic class even if that manufacturer didn't provide a Maine Rx rebate, because it would be silly to do so.
He's got a budget to operate.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I've known some silly administrators.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The point is, he could do it.

The point is, he could... you're... you're... you're... you're troubled by a... by a statute which would allow a denial of authorization unless the drug company pays $100 to each member of the... of the legislature.
I... I gather you... you acknowledge that... that the authorization requirement in the statute has some unstated limitation upon it, or don't you acknowledge that?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: I believe that... that under the Court's preemption analysis we look to the primary purposes of the Medicaid statute and you seek to determine what Congress intended.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Does the authorization provision have some unstated limitation upon it, a limitation that is not in that sole provision alone?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: I believe that it doesn't, but even if it does--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It doesn't, so $100 to each legislator is okay?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --And... and... and when that offends Congress, Congress has the ability to act.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The real question is whether it has an unstated limitation that's sufficiently clear that it preempts the State law.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The real question is whether the unstated limitation is sufficiently clear to be preemptive of a State statute to the contrary.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: That's... that's correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, how is Congress--

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: The language of the statute is, a State may subject to prior authorization any covered outpatient drug.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --Well, how could Congress--

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: Every--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --Sorry.
No, go ahead.
Finish, please.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --Indeed, every outpatient drug could be subjected to prior authorization.
That, too, would be silly, but the power is that broad.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Now, that's what I want to know.
Why?

I mean, how could Congress possibly want a statute which would hurt the Medicaid patients at... no argument it wouldn't hurt some of them, and has nothing to be said for helping anyone related to Medicaid?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: Well, we... we disagree that--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I know you disagree about whether that's the effect.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --that it will not hurt people.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I understand that.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So how can I decide this case without knowing whether the people in charge of the statute agree with you about that, as they might, or you might negotiate some implementation of how to have regulations that they can agree to, or, or, or, the possibilities are endless.
How can I decide in your favor, in other words, without knowing, the same question, what the Secretary thinks?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: Because the Secretary can act if the injunction... if the First Circuit's decision is affirmed, the Secretary can act, and tell the State of Maine we believe that you will harm Medicaid beneficiaries and we will take your money away.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But suppose--

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: But the Secretary hasn't acted.

The Secretary asked this Court to approve his notions of what Maine Rx might look like if it were more limited in scope in terms of the number of beneficiaries, but he hasn't defined for the Court how to set the line.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Suppose the State passes a law that says that each Medicaid beneficiary shall pay an additional tax of $50 a year.
You say that the only way to get rid of that law, which would certainly contravene the... the whole purpose of Medicaid.
The only way to get rid of it is to go to the Secretary and say, since this law is an amendment of the State's plan, you should approve it, it requires your approval.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: Now, there--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They couldn't strike that down as just being contrary to the--

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --No, it's contrary to the statute.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Okay.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: Medicaid beneficiaries can't be required to pay more than a nominal co-pay.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Okay, so--

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: Congress thought--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --So the only remedy for something that is contrary to the statute is not going through the Secretary, that some things that are contrary to the statute can be attacked directly, as is being done here.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --But... but I'm not convinced that from the text of the statute you can find an intent--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Okay.
That's a different question.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --on the part of Congress to prohibit this, and even if it were to... Congress were to prohibit using Maine Rx like prior authorizations for some purpose wholly unrelated to health care, when you get closer and closer to something approaching what the Secretary in fact does approve of, how can a court set the line?
The question really is--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That's the merits question, rather than whether we have, you know, power to... to move at all, so long as the Secretary can handle the problem by denying approval.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --The Secretary has indicated that he'll handle the problem, or he's expressed his views about what the program is.
The Court should wait to see whether the... I mean, the Court should allow the Secretary to--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Can I ask you this question: I thought you would agree that, if it were clear as a matter of fact that this program was going to harm Medicaid recipients, that we would have power to enjoin the program?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --Yes, but it's not... I do agree with that.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So your argument, as I understand it, it's an unresolved factual question whether, in fact, these adverse consequences would follow?

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: That's correct.

We have... there's no facts in the record, and... and this... this is a facial challenge in which my colleague has to demonstrate that they are in no way... there's no possibility of implementing the program in a way which doesn't cause harm to--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, I may not agree with that statement, but at least they have to make a showing there in fact will be an adverse effect.

turn.speaker: andrew_s_hagler
turn.label: Mr. Andrew S. Hagler
turn.text: --Some showing.
